column3: romanized: anfa - sṭṭat) is one of the twelve administrative regions of Morocco. It covers an area of 20
column4: 166 km² and recorded a population of 6
column7: 69% of which lived in urban areas. The capital of the region is Casablanca.

column1: Casablanca-Settat is located on the Atlantic coast. It borders the regions of Rabat-Salé-Kénitra to the northeast
column3: and Marrakesh-Safi to the south. Part of the border with Marrakesh-Safi follows the course of the Oum Er-Rbia River
column4: which flows northwest and empties into the Atlantic at Azemmour. The river divides the region into two plains
column5: the Doukkala in the west and the Chaouia in the east. Several reservoirs provide water for the region
column6: including that of the Al Massira Dam on the Oum Er-Rbia and one on the Oued Mellah south of Mohammedia.

column1: Casablanca-Settat was formed in September 2015 by merging Grand Casablanca with the provinces of El Jadida and Sidi Bennour in Doukkala-Abda region and the provinces of Benslimane
column2: Berrechid and Settat in Chaouia-Ouardigha region.
a member of the Authenticity and Modernity Party
column3: was elected as the first president of Casablanca-Settat's regional council on 14 September 2015. Khalid Safir was appointed governor (wali) of the region on 13 October 2015. He was succeeded by Abdelkébir Zahoud in 2017.

column1: Casablanca-Settat comprises two prefectures and seven provinces:
Casablanca-Settat had a gross domestic product of 290 billion Moroccan dirhams in 2013
column2: accounting for 32% of Morocco's GDP and ranking first among Moroccan regions. Its economy is primarily based on services and industry. In addition
column3: the Doukkala area in the west is noted for its agricultural output.
and A7 expressways connect Casablanca with Rabat
column5: and Marrakesh (via Berrechid and Settat) respectively. There is also an expressway running from Berrechid to Beni Mellal. Railways link the region with Marrakesh to the south
column7: and Rabat and other Moroccan cities to the northeast. The ports at Casablanca
column8: Jorf Lasfar and Mohammedia ranked second through fourth nationally by tonnage in 2014. Mohammed V International Airport
column9: located 20 km south of Casablanca in Nouaceur Province
column11: handling nearly eight million passengers in 2014. The country's only oil refinery in Mohammedia shut down in August 2015.
